source.56601b78:
activity <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/dailyActivity_merged.csv")
calories <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/hourlyCalories_merged.csv")
intensities <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/hourlyIntensities_merged.csv")
sleep <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/sleepDay_merged.csv")
weight <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/weightLogInfo_merged.csv")
steps_hourly <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/hourlySteps_merged.csv")
steps_daily <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/dailySteps_merged.csv")
heartrate <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/heartrate_seconds_merged.csv")

source.1329d236:
# intensities
intensities$ActivityHour=as.POSIXct(intensities$ActivityHour, format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
intensities$time <- format(intensities$ActivityHour, format = "%H:%M:%S")
intensities$date <- format(intensities$ActivityHour, format = "%m/%d/%y")
# calories
calories$ActivityHour=as.POSIXct(calories$ActivityHour, format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
calories$time <- format(calories$ActivityHour, format = "%H:%M:%S")
calories$date <- format(calories$ActivityHour, format = "%m/%d/%y")
# activity
activity$ActivityDate=as.POSIXct(activity$ActivityDate, format="%m/%d/%Y", tz=Sys.timezone())
activity$date <- format(activity$ActivityDate, format = "%m/%d/%y")
# sleep
sleep$SleepDay=as.POSIXct(sleep$SleepDay, format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
sleep$date <- format(sleep$SleepDay, format = "%m/%d/%y")
# steps
steps_hourly$ActivityHour=as.POSIXct(steps_hourly$ActivityHour, format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
steps_hourly$time <- format(steps_hourly$ActivityHour, format = "%H:%M:%S")
steps_hourly$date <- format(steps_hourly$ActivityHour, format = "%m/%d/%y")

source.3e970aa9:
# activity
activity %>%  
  select(TotalSteps, TotalDistance,
         SedentaryMinutes, Calories) %>%
  summary()

# explore number of active minutes per category
activity %>%
  select(VeryActiveMinutes, FairlyActiveMinutes, LightlyActiveMinutes) %>%
  summary()

# exploring intensities
intensities %>% select(TotalIntensity, AverageIntensity) %>%
summary()


# calories
calories %>%
  select(Calories) %>%
  summary()

# sleep
sleep %>%
  select(TotalSleepRecords, TotalMinutesAsleep, TotalTimeInBed) %>%
  summary()

# weight
weight %>%
  select(WeightKg, BMI) %>%
  summary()

# heartrate
heartrate %>% select(Value) %>%
summary()
source.54ebc84d:
ggplot(data=activity, aes(x=TotalSteps, y=Calories)) + 
  geom_point() + geom_smooth(method="gam") + labs(title="Total Steps vs. Calories")
source.9d7f542c:
ggplot(data=sleep, aes(x=TotalMinutesAsleep, y=TotalTimeInBed)) + 
  geom_jitter()+ labs(title="Total Minutes Asleep vs. Total Time in Bed")
source.1f0b85c7:
# intensity
intens_new <- intensities %>%
  group_by(time) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  summarise(mean_total_int = mean(TotalIntensity))

ggplot(data=intens_new, aes(x=time, y=mean_total_int)) + geom_histogram(stat = "identity", fill='blue') +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) +
  labs(title="Average Total Intensity vs. Time")

source.83128aed:

geom_point(color='blue') + geom_smooth() +
  labs(title="Minutes Asleep vs. Sedentary Minutes")
source.66b459a7: ### Some things to note: * Here we can clearly see the negative relationship between Sedentary Minutes and Sleep time. * As an idea: **if Bellabeat users want to improve their sleep, Bellabeat app can recommend reducing sedentary time.** * Keep in mind that we need to support this insights with more data, because correlation between some data doesn’t mean causation. # 6. Phase SHARE By observing about 30 participants that most of them had high sedentary minutes, low amounts of daily steps, and some clients didn't use all of the features. There are a lot of zeros and some of the sedentary minutes at 1440 (which is 24 hours). We can suggest that the participant either left their watch at home to charge and didn't want to use it that day, or maybe they just forgot it at home. After analyzing FitBit Fitness Tracker Data, I found some **insights that would help influence Bellabeat marketing strategy.** **Target audience** Women who work full-time jobs (according to the hourly intensity data) and spend a lot of time at the computer/in a meeting/ focusing on work they are doing (according to the sedentary time data). According to the activity analysis these women do some light activity to stay healthy. But they need to improve their everyday activity to have health benefits. They might need some knowledge about developing healthy habits or motivation to keep going. **The key message for the Bellabeat online campaign** The Bellabeat app is not just another fitness activity app. It’s a guide (a friend) who empowers women to balance full personal and professional life and healthy habits and routines by educating and motivating them through daily app recommendations. ### Recommendations for the Bellabeat app 1. Average total steps per day are 7638 which a little bit less for having health benefits for according to the CDC research. They found that taking 8,000 steps per day was associated with a 51% lower risk for all-cause mortality (or death from all causes). Taking 12,000 steps per day was associated with a 65% lower risk compared with taking 4,000 steps. Bellabeat can encourage people to take at least 8 000 explaining the benefits for their health. 2. If users want to lose weight, it’s probably a good idea to control daily calorie consumption. Bellabeat can suggest some ideas for low-calorie lunch and dinner. 3. Most activity happens between 5 pm and 7 pm - Bellabeat can use this time to remind and motivate users to go for a run or walk. 4. If users want to improve their sleep, the Bellabeat app also can recommend reducing sedentary time and send notification about sleeping time. **Thank you** for your interest to my Bellabeat Case Study! I will be happy to improve my work. Anastasia Sergeeva
source.568b22e7:
### 4.3 Visualization

### Graph 1. Total Steps vs Calories
source.81215184: There is the positive correlation in the Graph between Total Steps and Calories, which is obvious - the more active we are, the more calories we burn.
source.af5013f9:
### Some things to note:

* Participants are very clearly sedentary as their sedentary minutes eclipse all other intensities. The average sedentary time is 991 minutes or 1 hours.
* Most of the participants are lightly active.
* On the average the users sleep 7 hours one time per day, which is in the range of recommended hours.
* Average total steps per day are 7638 which a little bit less for having health benefits for according to the CDC research. They found that taking 8,000 steps per day was associated with a 51% lower risk for all-cause mortality (or death from all causes). Taking 12,000 steps per day was associated with a 65% lower risk compared with taking 4,000 steps.
* The average heart rate is 77 BPM (beats per minute) which is in the range of the average BPM.


### 4.2 Merging data

Before visualization, I merge 2 data sets through inner join: **activity** and **sleep** on columns Id and date (that were previously created by converting data to date time format).
source.02e72a01:
#### 3.4 Importing the Datasets

Datasets used:
* Daily Activity, 
* Hourly Calories, 
* Hourly Intensities, 
* Seep Day, 
* Weight Log, 
* Daily Steps
source.e222094a:
#### 3.5 Preview of the Datasets
All of these datasets were also checked on Google Sheets except for heart rate, which was too big to open. With the **head() function** I checked all the datasets.
source.49f81ece:
#### 3.6 Fixing formatting of a few datasets to separate their dates and times

There are some problems with the timestamp data. It must be converted to *date time* format, as well as date to be separated from time. I use **date-time conversion functions as.POSIXct()**.
source.44effbf1: # 1. Introduction This is a case study for Bellabeat, the high-tech company that manufactures smart health-focused products catered for women. The goal of this study will be to analyze and gain insight into how consumers use the **FitBit**, a popular smartwatch brand, in their daily lives and apply these insights to **Time**, the Bellabeat-created smartwatch. The Bellabeat app provides users with health data related to their activity, sleep, stress, menstrual cycle, and mindfulness habits. This data can help users better understand their current habits and make healthy decisions. The Bellabeat app connects to their line of smart wellness products # 2. Phase ASK #### 2.1 Business Task Identify potential opportunities for growth and recommendations for the Bellabeat marketing strategy improvement based on trends in smart device usage. #### 2.2 Stakeholders * Urška Sršen - Bellabeat cofounder and Chief Creative Officer * Sando Mur - Bellabeat cofounder and key member of Bellabeat executive team * Bellabeat Marketing Analytics team #### 2.3 Questions for the analysis 1. What are some trends in smart device usage? 2. How could these trends apply to Bellabeat customers? 3. How could these trends help influence Bellabeat marketing strategy #### 2.4 Limitations * There is not enough weight data. So, it's impossible to analyse weight trends. * The smart device is produced specially for women, but there is no information like tracking menstrual cycle, fertile window etc, * We don't possess other key informartion such as stress level and lifestyle factors, demographics of the sample population.
source.483c66f9:

It's important to see how many unique IDs each dataset has, because it is clear from the smaller datasets that there aren't 30 in each one.

source.20c95c68:
### Some things to note:

The CDC (Centers for Deasease Control and Prevention, US) recommend most adults aim for 10 000 steps** in per day for a healthy lifestyle. 
However, **the average total steps** of the participants only came out to about **7600**, while the **sedentary minutes** were at the average **990 minutes (16.5 hours)**. 

We can see it in the graph a congregation of points below 10000 steps and above 1000 minutes. It shows these participants live sedentary lifestyle. 

In order to get consumers moving, setting up alerts for consumers by having them set daily goals to move around more could bring their total steps up and sedentary minutes down.

### Graph 3. Total Minutes Asleep vs. Total Time in Bed
source.6563e9d2:
The relationship between Total Minutes Asleep and Total Time in Bed looks linear.
**So, the Bellabeat can offer customers to use notifications to improve their sleep.**


### Graphs 4, 5. Intensity and Steps over time (hourly)
source.062dc97e:
There are:

* 33 participants in the activity, calories, intensities and both steps data sets, 
* 24 in the sleep dataset,
* 14 in the heart rate dataset,
* only 8 in the weight data set.

This means we will not be able to use the Weight Log dataset, as 8 participants is too little to make any significant analysis or conclusion. However, the others are still fair game. So, let's now summarize their contents.
source.1e52a37f: The Sleep dataset turned out to have a few duplicates which were cleaned during the next step:
source.6275e4d9:
### Some things to note:

* People are more active between 6 am and 10 pm.

* Most activity happens between 5 pm and 7 pm - probably, people go to a gym or for a walk after finishing work. 
This fact can **be used by the Bellabeat app to remind and motivate consumers to go for a run or walk.**

### Graph 5. Relationship between Total Minutes Asleep and Sedentry Minutes
source.1c6b2d1b: # 3. Phase PREPARE & PROCESS #### 3.1 Data Source and its credibility * It's public data from [FitBit Fitness Tracker Data](http://www.kaggle.com/arashnic/fitbit): contains daily personal activity information of 30 fitbit users, that includes minute-level output for physical activity, heart rate, and sleep monitoring. It's a good database segmented in several tables with different aspects of the data of the device with lots of details about the user behaviour. #### 3.2 Limitations * The size of the data sample is not large enough which will limit scope for analysis * We have no information of the key demographics of the sample population, nor any info of their lifestyle factors * No units specified for any of the distance columns, however we can safely assume it is kilometers based on the TotalSteps column #### 3.3 Importing Packages I chose the following packages that help the analysis:
